input.content:
You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action

Task Description:
I will ask you a question, then you should help me operate a MySQL database with SQL to answer the question.
You have to explain the problem and your solution to me and write down your thoughts.
After thinking and explaining thoroughly, every round you can choose to operate or to answer.
your operation should be like this:
Action: Operation
```sql
SELECT * FROM table WHERE condition;
```
You MUST put SQL in markdown format without any other comments. Your SQL should be in one line.
Every time you can only execute one SQL statement. I will only execute the statement in the first SQL code block. Every time you write a SQL, I will execute it for you and give you the output.
If you are done operating, and you want to commit your final answer, then write down:
Action: Answer
Final Answer: ["ANSWER1", "ANSWER2", ...]
DO NOT write this pattern unless you are sure about your answer. I expect an accurate and correct answer.
Your answer should be accurate. Your answer must be exactly the same as the correct answer.
If the question is about modifying the database, then after done operation, your answer field can be anything.
If your response cannot match any pattern I mentioned earlier, you will be judged as FAIL immediately.
Your input will be raw MySQL response, you have to deal with it by yourself.

bash: no job control in this shell

{
  "analysis": "I checked the environment. The mysql client was not originally present, so I installed default-mysql-client successfully (mysql 8.0.44). There is no local MySQL/MariaDB server running: attempts to connect to localhost failed with ERROR 2002 (can't connect to socket). There are no environment variables or /root/.my.cnf with credentials, and no process listening on port 3306. The filesystem has the client configuration fallback files under /etc/mysql (installed with the client), but no data directory (/var/lib/mysql) or socket was found. Therefore I cannot run SQL against any server from here until I either have connection details for a remote server or we install and start a local MySQL/MariaDB server in this container.",
  "plan": "I will not perform any intrusive changes without your confirmation. You can choose one of the following paths:

Option A — Use a remote/existing MySQL server (recommended if you have a DB elsewhere):
- Provide connection details: host (or IP), port (default 3306), username, and password (or indicate if socket or .my.cnf should be used). Optionally provide database name. Once you provide credentials I will produce exactly one SQL statement (in the required markdown format) for you to execute; you will run it and paste the output, and we will iterate.

Option B — Install and start a local MySQL/MariaDB server inside the container (I will do this only if you explicitly allow it):
- I will run apt-get install mariadb-server (or mysql-server) and initialize/start the server, then connect as root with an insecure temporary password or root without password (depending on init method). After the server is running I can execute the SQL you request. Installing and running a DB server in the container is more invasive and may take additional time.

If you choose Option B, here are the exact commands I plan to run (one-at-a-time, with your confirmation):
1) apt-get update
2) DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive apt-get install -y mariadb-server
3) (start the server) service mysql start || systemctl start mariadb || mysqld_safe &
4) mysql -uroot -e "SHOW DATABASES;"

If you choose Option A, provide the connection details and I will craft a single SQL statement in the format you required (Action: Operation and a single-line SQL inside a markdown code block). After you run it and paste back the output, I will continue.

Tell me which option you want (A: provide connection details, or B: allow installing a local server). If you pick B, confirm and I will proceed. If you pick A, give me host, port, user, and password (or indicate existing .my.cnf or socket path).",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

{
  "analysis": "Current state: the mysql client is installed in the container (mysql 8.0.44), but there is no MySQL/MariaDB server running locally and there are no credentials or config files present. Attempts to connect to localhost fail with ERROR 2002. I cannot run any SQL against a database until I either connect to a remote server with credentials you provide or install and start a local server inside this container.",
  "plan": "I will wait for your choice. You can choose one of two safe options:

Option A — Connect to an existing (remote or local) MySQL server: provide connection details (host or socket path, port if nonstandard, username, and password). If you provide these, I will produce the single SQL statement you want in the exact format you required (Action: Operation with one SQL statement in a markdown code block). You will run that SQL and paste the raw MySQL output back; I will parse it and continue.

Option B — Install and start a local MySQL/MariaDB server inside the container: confirm you want this. If you confirm, I will run package installation and start the server, then connect and run the SQL statements you instruct. This is more invasive and may take additional time.

Please reply with either:
- Option A and the connection details (host, port, user, password, optional database), or
- Option B to allow me to install and start a local server.

When you want me to execute SQL, remember I will output exactly one SQL statement inside a single markdown code block preceded by "Action: Operation" as you specified. You will execute only the SQL in that first code block and return the output.",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",

      "duration": 0.1
    },

}

Optional fields:

- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",

      "duration": 0.1
    },

      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action
